subsection.name: 2.1 System Requirements
subsection.p: Cayenne, including GUI tools, is written in 100% Java, and therefore should run out of the box on any Java-compatible platform. More detailed requirements are listed below:

- JSDK 1.4 : Cayenne requires JSDK 1.4 or newer and will not run with earlier versions. To download it from Sun go to http://java.sun.com/products/ or directly to http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4/index.html
- Operating System compatible with JSDK 1.4 : Currently this is Linux, Solaris and Windows 95 / 98 / ME / 2000 / NT 4.0. MacOS support should be coming soon.

- Access to a relational database and JDBC driver for this database : Out of the box, Cayenne would support Oracle, Sybase, MySQL and PostgreSQL databases. Certain level of support exists for any other database that has a JDBC driver available but this is untested and not guaranteed. List of available JDBC drivers can be found at
http://industry.java.sun.com/products/jdbc/drivers. Note that to run Cayenne unit tests you will need "CREATE TABLE" and "DROP TABLE" database privileges since tests supplied with Cayenne will create all the tables on the fly.

- (Optional) Ant 1.4.1 : Users who downloaded source or binary distribution WILL NOT need Ant. Only if you plan to build it yourself (you don't have to!), you will need Ant. Version 1.4.1 or newer is required, older versions will not work. Ant can be downloaded from http://jakarta.apache.org/ant/index.html.

subsection.name: 2.2 Installation
subsection.p: This section describes the steps needed to install Cayenne source or binary distribution.

Download Cayenne from http://objectstyle.org/cayenne/download.html. Choose the type of download that fits your needs. If you need a stable version, download source or binary release. To get the latest features, download source or binary nightly build (of course when using nightly builds users run into the risks accociated with running development code). Downloaded file is called something like cayenne-[release-suffix].tar.gz.

Unpack cayenne-[release-suffix].tar.gz into the target installation directory. On Windows you can use WinZip to unpack the distribution. WinZip supports UNIX .tar.gz archives, therefore Cayenne is not provided as a zip file. On UNIX, run the following command:

To take advantage of the scripts located in the bin directory of Cayenne, set the following environment variables:
CAYENNE_HOME - should point to the directory created when your unpacked Cayenne distribution in the previous steps. (Directory named like cayenne-[release-suffix]).
JAVA_HOME - should point to your JSDK 1.4 installation. It may already exist in the environment.
Note that these variables are only necessary to use the scripts that run unit tests and start CayenneModeler. They are probably not needed on a deployment machine.
Installation is complete.

subsection.name: 2.3 Cayenne JAR Files
subsection.p: There are two JAR files in [cayenne_install_dir]/lib directory: cayenne.jar and cayenne-nodeps.jar. Either one or another should be used (but not both of them at the same time). In most cases cayenne.jar is the best choice. It has Cayenne classes as well as all the needed dependencies. Dependencies include Velocity Template Engine classes, and are bundled with Cayenne for simpler installation and configuration. A leaner cayenne-nodeps.jar file should only be used if Velocity is already installed on the user machine or a user wants to install it herself. Note that Cayenne was tested with Velocity version 1.3. There is no guarantee that it will work with other versions.

Make sure that [cayenne_install_dir]/lib/cayenne.jar is accessible by the applications that use Cayenne. This can be done in many different ways depending on what you are planning to use Cayenne for. The simplest way is to copy cayenne.jar (or cayenne-nodeps.jar to your JRE extensions directory ($JRE_HOME/lib/ext or $JAVA_HOME/jre/lib/ext).

subsection.panel: Use "-nogui" flag when calling runtests.sh if you need to run tests in command line mode with no GUI (for example, for remote installations). For things like automated unit tests "-xml [filename]" can be supplied on the command line to allow test script to read database info from an XML file.
subsection.p: Enter you database login information, JDBC driver class and database URL. JDBC driver class must be accessible by Java Virtual Machine. For example you can put a database vendor JAR file containing the driver in $JAVA_HOME/jre/lib/ext directory. Note that there is a combo box in the top left corner of the login panel that allows user to select a canned driver and URL information. You must overwrite any of the canned data to provide the information that matches your environment.
Test results will be printed in a terminal window.

subsection.name: 2.5 Compiling Cayenne from Source
subsection.panel: Normally users don't need to compile Cayenne. Prebuilt JAR's are included with both source and binary distributions.
